repnme.cdata!:
Improving healthcare and quality of life
            for people living with HIV and AIDS in Brazil

abstracts.cdata!:
The government has invested heavily in
            the prevention and treatment of human immunodeficiency virus
            (HIV) and acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) and
            other sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), targeting groups
            most at risk, and offering antiretroviral treatment - free
            of charge -to all identified patients who qualify for it. In
            recent years, the epidemic has been spreading to women,
            poorer groups, and towards the interior of the country. In
            May 2010, the World Bank approved a United States (U.S.) 67
            million dollars loan to Brazil, in support of the federal
            AIDS- Brazil's unified health system (SUS) project,
            aiming at increasing prevention, care, and treatment
            services for groups most at risk of HIV and AIDS and STDs.
            The project will also support the governments efforts to
            improve health program performance through improved
            governance, decentralization, and results-based management.
            The project will also map the epidemic and the health
            response for groups most at risk by region.

docna.cdata!:
Improving healthcare and quality of life for
            people living with HIV and AIDS in Brazil

TF092341-BRAZIL - HIV/AIDS SURVEILLANCE
            AND M&E,TF035147-BRAZIL - AIDS AND STD CONTROL PROJECT,TF039297-BRAZIL - AIDS II,TF039469-BRAZIL - AIDS II & DISEASE

            AND AIDS II

repnme.cdata!: Brazil - Second AIDS and STD Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was highly likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory,. The lessons learned indicate that the
            strategic focus of the activities in the project served as a
            catalyst for change, including attracting additional
            investment, promoting change, and protecting program
            investments from political influence, particularly at the
            municipal level. Even though the project collected
            significant amounts of data on HIV/AIDS and Sexually
            Transmitted Deseases (STDs), it was not possible to assess
            trends over time since the use of differing methodologies
            resulted in inconsistencies that could not be interpreted.
            An adequate monitoring and evaluation system was not
            established. If AIDS II had financed administrative costs on
            a declining basis, the Ministry of Health (MOH) would have
            had fewer incentives to rely on external consultants. The
            project significantly underestimated the administrative
            demands incurred by the evaluation of more than 2,000
            projects executed by civil society. Decentralization of
            management responsibilities to states and municipalities
            implies a change in roles for all players. The current
            system allows states and municipalities to make better use
            of resources at the local level, by increasing synergy with
            other programs and reducing duplication of efforts. The
            number of hospitalizations per AIDS patient declined from
            1.6 in 1996, before ART was introduced, to 0.3 in 2001, for
            an estimated 358,000 hospitalizations prevented during
            1997-2001. Providing ART free of charge is not enough to
            make everyone come forward for treatment.

0.cdata!: Specific Investment Loan

4266959.trustfund:
TF039297-BRAZIL - AIDS II,TF039469-BRAZIL - AIDS II & DISEASE
            SURVEILLANCE CONTROL PROJECT,TF040402-BRAZIL:  AIDS AND STD CONTROL PROJECT,TF040440-BRAZIL:  DISEASE SURVEILLANCE
            AND AIDS II

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - First and Second AIDS and STD
            Control Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
AIDS I and II have had limited success
            in strengthening Brazil's surveillance of HIV infection
            and of behaviors among priority populations. This has
            undermined Brazil's ability to evaluate the impact of
            its prevention efforts on behaviors and on the epidemiology
            of the disease. Inadequate data on the size and coverage of
            target populations for the prevention and treatment
            programs, respectively, especially at the state and local
            levels, undermine the efficiency and effectiveness of
            HIV/AIDS interventions. Early, rigorous and sustained
            prevention efforts are likely to keep the pool of I&V
            and AIDS patients small relative to the counterfactual, and
            thus to reduce the burden on a country's health system
            and make treatment and care more feasible and affordable.
            NGOs have a critical role to play in the fight against
            HIV/AIDS. Even when financing a relatively modest share of
            the overall costs of a well-established program, Bank
            support to HIV/AIDS efforts can make significant
            contributions to program expansion and capacity building
            when it is strategically allocated. Bank support can bring
            legitimacy and leverage to controversial activities and to
            stigmatized segments of society. A research program that is
            ad hoc and uncoordinated in its conception likely to
            generate a large volume of information and data that will be
            difficult to is interpret and use for measuring and
            improving program performance and impact. Project design and
            conditionality can be strategic in initiating and supporting
            institutional innovations which are capable of expanding and
            using more fully program implementation capacity.

Brazil - First and Second AIDS and STD
            Control Projects

repnme.cdata!: Stemming the HIV or AIDS epidemic in Brazil

abstracts.cdata!:
In 1990, Brazil had one of the
            world's largest numbers of reported acquired
            immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) cases in the world. In
            1993, the World Bank approved 160 million dollars for the
            AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases (STD) Control Project
            in Brazil. The program focused on prevention efforts, but
            also covered treatment and testing. Aided by another 165
            million dollars World Bank loan in 1998, the Control
            Project, in its second phase, is helping Brazil's
            ministry of health reduce the spread of human
            immunodeficiency virus (HIV) or AIDS while making it
            possible for Brazilians with AIDS to live longer, healthier
            lives. The program has contributed to a 38 percent drop in
            the number of AIDS-related deaths since 1993. While
            supporting 145 specialized AIDS care units, 66
            hospital-based care units, and 50 home-care teams, the focus
            of the Second AIDS and STD Project remains prevention. It
            has helped set up a nationwide network of 141 AIDS testing
            and counseling centers. Through a partnership with the
            national business AIDS council, 3,000 companies are now
            providing AIDS awareness training to 3.5 million workers.

docna.cdata!: Stemming the HIV or AIDS epidemic in Brazil

            immunodeficiency virus (HIV) or AIDS while making it
            possible for Brazilians with AIDS to live longer, healthier
            lives. The program has contributed to a 38 percent drop in
            the number of AIDS-related deaths since 1993. While
            supporting 145 specialized AIDS care units, 66
            hospital-based care units, and 50 home-care teams, the focus
            of the Second AIDS and STD Project remains prevention. It
            has helped set up a nationwide network of 141 AIDS testing
            and counseling centers. Through a partnership with the
            national business AIDS council, 3,000 companies are now
            providing AIDS awareness training to 3.5 million workers.

repnme.cdata!: Brazil - Second AIDS and STD Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Second Aids and
            STD Control Project are: 1) to reduce the incidence of HIV
            and STD infection and 2) expand and improve diagnosis,
            treatment, and care of persons with HIV, AIDS, and STD. The
            project components include: 1) AIDS and STD prevention, 2)
            diagnosis, treatment and care for HIV, AIDS, and STD
            patients, and 3) strengthening of public and private
            institutions for AIDS/STD control.
